question.title: How to get a filepath from a unix system using java where the path is {{parameters.secret-path}}/file
question.body:
Currently there is a unix-based system that exposes a file in what the team is saying would be {{parameters.secret-path}}/file. I am not sure how to read that in java given the enclosing of double curly braces and not sure what that means. I have tried using the NIO library and trying to get Path.of(System.getenv("parameters.secret-path"), "file.txt").toString(); and also tried Path.of(System.getProperty("parameters.secret-path"), "file.txt").toString(); but each time it is coming as null and unable to find that path. I'm not entirely familiar with the double curly braces what that looks like in a unix-like system, so I'm sure there could be something I'm missing. Let know if anyone has any suggestions on properly finding this path as it isn't a root path.

The goal is to be able to find some ssl cert paths as String to properly build SSL properties for a java sql connection for a postgresql db.

question_comments.body: You might have taken literally what they meant figuratively. For one thing most shells cannot contain hyphens in environment variables

{{parameters.secret-path}} feels like it's a part of a different system, say like EL (expression language) scripts from JSP. Ask. It's not a bad question if you've missed the context where this is from.
